Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: SHINE: Observational and Theoretical Investigation of Solar Flare Ribbon Elongation
Award.AbstractNarration:
This 3-year collaborative SHINE project will provide new physical insights into the energy release in solar flares, which is an important component of space weather research and is of high importance to society at large. The project will explore the physical processes of magnetic reconnection spreading and particle energization, which have applications beyond the SHINE program. Thus, the expected outcome of this project should be of use for applications in the Earth's magnetosphere, and potentially laboratory and fusion experiments. The project activities will promote training and learning through the funding of two graduate students. The lead PI will continue to supervise undergraduate students' research through an NSF-sponsored REU program at the MSU. Thus far, the lead PI has supervised 13 REU students, with six of them being female students. The non-lead PI will continue his productive partnership with the Children's Discovery Museum of West Virginia as part of this project. The research and EPO agenda of this project supports the Strategic Goals of the AGS Division in discovery, learning, diversity, and interdisciplinary research.

This collaborative SHINE project will explore a novel and independent technique to estimate magnetic fields at reconnection sites high in the solar corona. This region of the solar atmosphere is currently inaccessible to direct observations, and therefore of great interest to the SHINE community. The project team will determine observationally and numerically whether there is a correlation between the guide magnetic field strength and particle acceleration; a link between the two would provide a novel way to estimate particle acceleration from observations of solar-flare ribbon spreading. The problem of magnetic reconnection spreading is of broad interest to the SHINE community for a number of applications, including prominence eruptions, and greatly expanding the region of reconnection in the turbulent solar wind.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From 2014 through 2019, the National Science Foundation has supported the research project to understand properties of magnetic reconnection and how they govern energetics in terms of particle acceleration and plasma heating in solar flares. The research group at the Montana State University, composed of the faculty PI, graduate and undergraduate students, and postdoctoral research associates, has conducted novel observational analyses to explore properties of magnetic reconnection.

 Magnetic reconnection is an important physical process in magnetized plasmas in space or astrophysics environment. Plasmas made of electrons and ions are highly conductive, and they are usually thought to be ``frozen" in magnetic field, which is ubiquitous in the outer space. The turbulence motion inside the Sun generates complex magnetic field that emerges into the Sun's outer atmosphere, where a large amount of energy is stored in the form of electric currents. Magnetic reconnection is such a physical process that suddenly changes the connectivity of magnetic field lines near the current concentration, and consequently changes the global configuration of magnetic field to a state with a lower magnetic stress and magnetic energy. In this course, the excess magnetic energy is used to accelerate charged particles (electrons and ions) to high speeds, and heat plasmas to high temperatures. Although the general picture of flare energy release via magnetic reconnection is well accepted, exactly how magnetic reconnection converts magnetic energy into particles and plasmas has been an outstanding question in solar physics, space physics, and astrophysics.

The research conducted at the Montana State University is aimed to seeking clues to answer this long-standing question through analyses of state-of-the-art solar flare observations obtained by several satellites. The group has developed and standardized a method to measure the rate of magnetic reconnection, which has been applied to a large number of flares very efficiently. Furthermore, the group has been exploring new avenues to measure properties of three-dimensional magnetic reconnection, in particular, the magnetic guide field in the reconnection current sheet. The magnetic guide field is parallel to the electric current and electric field, and it may play a critical role affecting particle acceleration by the parallel electric field, or governing reconnection dynamics, such as generation of magnetic islands, a signature of turbulent magnetic reconnection, which can also accelerate particles. The research group at Montana State University has also analyzed flare X-ray observations by the Ramaty High Energy Solar Spectroscopic Imager to derive the photon spectral index describing electron energy distribution as well as plasma temperature, and examine how these properties indicating particle and plasma energetics are related to reconnection properties.

With comprehensive analyses of more than two dozen flares, which is the first large-sample study of this kind, the research has revealed that electrons are accelerated to high energy with a hard spectrum, and plasmas are heated to a very high temperature of up to 30 million kelvin degrees, at the time when the rate of magnetic reconnection peaks. Within this sample, it is also evident that flares with greater magnetic reconnection rate give rise to larger hard X-ray fluxes as well as higher peak plasma temperatures. These provide a strong evidence that flare energetics are directly relevant to magnetic reconnection. On the other hand, it is not entirely clear from this research how the magnetic guide field in the reconnection current sheet might govern flare energetics. The significance of the guide field in flare energetics is not as prominent as the reconnection rate, and its role may vary depending on individual flares, which deserves further investigation.

To estimate the magnetic guide field relative to the reconnection outflow field during the progress of magnetic reconnection, the research group has also measured the apparent motion of flare ribbons. Such apparent motion reflects dynamics of reconnection in the current sheet at the corona, which cannot be directly measured at present. In the studied flares, the apparent speed ranges between a few to up to 100 kilometers per second, and these provide constraints to theoretic modeling of reconnection process and current sheet structure, which is a major effort by the collaborators in this collaborative research project.

The project has supported graduate students and postdoctoral research associates in their early career. Undergraduate students have also been engaged in this research through the support by the National Science Foundation's Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program. These young researchers have been trained with a variety of observational analysis skills, and have learned to write research papers to be published in peer-reviewed journals, present research results at conferences, and communicate with a broader research community. These efforts support NSF's objective to promote education and training of the next generation in STEM areas.
